topic_name: iNode : direct data block address, single indirect, .. triple indirect, —> determines max file size

questions.question: An inode has 12 direct pointers, each pointing to a 4KB block. If the filesystem uses 32-bit block addresses, what is the maximum file size that can be addressed using ONLY direct pointers?
questions.explanation: With 12 direct pointers and 4KB blocks, the maximum size using only direct pointers is 12 × 4KB = 48KB. The size of block addresses doesn't affect this calculation.

questions.question: Why does a filesystem use indirect addressing (single, double, triple) instead of just increasing the number of direct pointers in an inode?
options: Indirect addressing is faster to access
It keeps inode size fixed while allowing very large files
Direct pointers can only address small blocks
Indirect addressing uses less disk space
questions.explanation: Indirect addressing allows the inode structure to remain a fixed, small size while still supporting very large files. Adding more direct pointers would make every inode larger, wasting space for small files.

questions.question: In a filesystem with 4KB blocks and 32-bit addressing, a single indirect block can contain how many block addresses, and what's the maximum additional file size it can address?
questions.explanation: A 4KB block can hold 4096 bytes ÷ 4 bytes per address = 1024 addresses. Each address points to a 4KB block, so 1024 × 4KB = 4MB additional file size.

questions.question: When would a file system need to use triple indirect addressing for a file?
options: When the file is larger than what direct + single + double indirect can address
When the file needs faster access times
When the file is fragmented across the disk
When the file needs better security
questions.explanation: Triple indirect addressing is only used when a file grows beyond the capacity of direct pointers, single indirect, and double indirect combined. It's the last resort for addressing very large files.

questions.question: Consider a filesystem where accessing each level of indirection requires one disk read. A file using triple indirect addressing would require how many disk reads to access a data block (assuming no caching)?
questions.explanation: To reach data through triple indirect: 1st read gets the single indirect address from double indirect block, 2nd read gets the data block address from single indirect block, 3rd read gets the double indirect address from triple indirect block, 4th read gets the actual data block.
